title: Margaret Connolly teaches at the University of St Andrews, and is a gene‐ral editor of The Mediaeval Journal and the Middle English Texts series. She has published editions of Middle English religious prose texts, the monograph John Shirley

container-title: and Insular Books: Vernacular Manuscript Miscellanies in Late Medieval Britain, with Raluca Radulescu

note: Her present research focuses on Early Modern English women translators, the relationship between print and translation, and translations into and out of Neo-Latin.
title: Hosington is a Professeure associée in the Département de lin‐guistique et traduction at the University of Montréal and Research Associate at the University of Warwick. She has published widely on medieval and Renaissance translation and is the editor of the database entitled Renaissance Cultural Crossroads: An Online Catalogue of Translations in Britain 1473-1640

title: Jones is Associate Professor of English Medieval Literature and Culture at the University of Exeter. He works on late-medieval religious writing and culture, with particular interests in hermits, anchorites, and other forms of semi-religious life. He has published editions of the fifteenth-­ century ­compilation Disce Mori

Since then she has been tea‐ching medieval literature to visiting students of Wycliffe Hall (University of Oxford). Veronica O’Mara is a Professor in the Department of English, University of Hull. Her main research areas are Middle English religious literature, female literacy, preaching, and the relationship between manuscript and print
